Department of Chemical Engineering Indian Institute of Technology Madras Chennai 600036 India Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai-600036, India. ⁎ Corresponding author. Lignin valorization is the key to sustainability of second-generation bioethanol refineries. In this study, the catalytic activities of Pd-Lewis acid metal oxides (Mo, Zr) supported on commercial activated carbon (AC) and activated biochar (ABC) were evaluated for the selective production of monomeric phenols from alkali lignin through transfer hydrogenolysis. The catalysts were thoroughly characterized for phase, degree of graphitization, textural properties, and metal dispersion. The Pd crystallite size was 2.1-2.5 Å in the case of AC-supported catalysts, while it was smaller (1.4-1.5 Å) for ABC-supported catalysts. AC exhibited better degree of graphitization than ABC. 2%Pd-5%Mo supported on AC showed good catalytic activity for the production of guaiacol, alkyl guaiacols, alkene guaiacols, and vanillin derivatives, and their respective yields were 4.2, 10.3, 3.4, and 12 wt.%. Compared to other alcohols like methanol and ethanol, the use of isopropyl alcohol as solvent resulted in better yields of guaiacol, alkyl guaiacols and alkene guaiacols. Condensation reactions of the guaiacyl unit and syringyl unit were confirmed through Fourier transform infrared spectroscopic analysis of the residue. Dimerization of monomeric phenols was observed with Pd-metal oxide supported on ABC than with AC-based catalyst. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin Transfer hydrogenolysis Lewis acid metal oxide Activated carbon Palladium Guaiacol Vanillin Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A wide range of aromatic compounds and commodity chemicals used as raw materials for making synthetic fibers, solvents, plasticizers, and plastic resins are made from petroleum crude oil [1,2]. Lignin, one of the abundant biopolymers on earth, is a promising fossil-substitute to make phenols and aromatic platform chemicals. The typical chemicals that are obtained from lignin via different depolymerization strategies include catechol, 4-propylguaiacol, phenol, and vanillin [1,3]. This is justified by the presence of p-hydroxyphenyl, guaiacyl, and syringyl monomeric units linked by aryl ether (β-O-4, α-O-4, 4-O-5) and carbon-carbon (β-1, β-5, 5-5, β-β) functionalities [4,5]. Nevertheless, the key challenge lies in selectively deriving the chemicals from lignin, which is exacerbated by the complex oxygen functionalities like methoxy, carbonyl, carboxyl, and hydroxyl organized in the branched lignin framework [6]. The pulp and paper industries solely produce 40-50 million tons per year of alkali lignin, while only lesser than 2% of that is being utilized for the production of chemicals [5]. A major fraction of lignin is today burnt for energy in recovery boilers, which is a low value application. This also results in greenhouse gas emissions. The market size of lignin in 2021 was 976.6 million USD, and is predicted to grow at an annual rate of 2.37% [7]. Catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis (CTH) has gained significant attention over other thermochemical methods like pyrolysis, hydrothermal liquefaction, oxidation, and gasification for the selective production of aromatics from lignin [6]. The advantages of CTH over the other methods include no requirement of external hydrogen, high carbon atom economy, better selectivity to monomers, low formation of char, and prevention of side reactions. Competitive adsorption of hydrogen and lignin molecule over the catalyst is responsible for the low yield and selectivity to monomers in hydrogenolysis assisted by H2 [7]. Therefore, the use of hydrogen-donating solvent assumes importance in CTH. Short-chain alcohols are the widely used solvents in the CTH of lignin due to similar values of the Hildebrand solubility parameter as that of alkali lignin [6]. Properties such as the solubility of lignin, hydrogen-donating capability, and hydrogen solubility are major factors to be considered in choosing the solvent for CTH [8]. Hydroxyl groups in lignin are also responsible for the in-situ production of hydrogen [9]. Various metal oxides (Nb2O5, TiO2, SiO2, Al2O3, CeO2, ZrO2), and zeolites (HZSM-5, H-Beta, MCM-41, MAS-7, and SAPO-11) [6,10] are commonly used as supports in CTH of lignin. The low surface area of metal oxides creates a negative impact on catalytic surface reactions, whereas zeolites lead to the formation of significant amount of char via repolymerization of monomers and aromatic ring hydrogenation due to its high Brønsted acidity [6,11]. To mitigate these issues, activated carbon (AC) has gained more attention owing to its inert surface under basic and acidic conditions. Moreover, tailoring the physical properties (pore size distribution and surface area) and chemical properties (polarity and hydrophobicity) are possible with AC. As only a small amount (<1%) of activated carbon that is produced worldwide is used as catalyst support [12], it is high time to focus on AC as a support for biomass conversion reactions including CTH. Kim et al. [13] studied the use of Ru/C catalyst for the transfer hydrogenolysis of organosolv lignin in water-ethanol mixture (1:3) combined with CO2. The highest liquid yield of ∼80 wt.% and phenolic monomer yield of ∼20 wt.% were obtained due to the production of carbonic acid at 300°C and low pH ∼ 3.0 of the solution. The ReOx/AC catalyst is shown to catalyze the cleavage of the β-O-4 and the more recalcitrant linkages like β-5 and β–β, while keeping the aromatic structure intact. Rhenium oxide and surface oxygen groups present in activated carbon are shown to be responsible for cleaving the C–O bonds [14]. When lignin-rich residue extracted from switchgrass through ionic liquid pre-treatment was subjected to Ru/C catalyst at 300°C using isopropyl alcohol, alkyl-substituted phenols were shown to be the dominant products. The liquid and monomer yields were 65.5 and 27 wt.%, respectively, under the optimum reaction conditions [13]. Cheng et al. [15] reported the production of phenolic monomers from organosolv poplar lignin at 63.4 wt.% yield using Ni-Cu/C catalyst in ethanol/isopropyl alcohol solvent system at 270°C and 4 h. Cu acted as a promoter to enhance the hydrogen donation process, while also facilitating the cleavage of C–C bonds of pinoresinol type structures. A combination of noble metal (Pd) and Lewis metal oxides (MoO3, WO2.6, ZrO2) showed promising results in alkali lignin hydrogenolysis assisted by H2. A total monomer selectivity of ∼80% was obtained using Pd-Mo supported on activated biochar catalyst. The conversion and liquid yield were 67% and 48 wt.%, respectively [16]. A higher degree of graphitization of carbon nanotubes (CNT)-supported Ru catalyst resulted in higher catalytic activity, and facilitated the cleavage of C–C and C–O bonds in sorbitol. This is shown to be due to the higher electron conductivity and higher graphitization that enhanced the electronic interactions between Ru and CNT [17]. While many studies have employed commercial AC as support, to the best of author's knowledge, the effects of degree of graphitization of different carbon support, and Pd-Lewis metal oxide (MoO3 and ZrO2) catalysts on product yield and selectivity during CTH of lignin are rarely explored. In this study, Pd-Lewis metal oxides (MoO3 and ZrO2) supported on activated biochar and commercial AC are used for CTH of alkali lignin to produce monomeric phenols. The catalysts are thoroughly characterized using a range of analytical techniques to evaluate the degree of graphitization, structure and textural properties. In addition to the role of catalysts, the role of short-chain alcohols like methanol, ethanol, and isopropyl alcohol are evaluated for the selective production of alkyl guaiacols and vanillin derivatives. The regenerated lignin obtained after hydrogenolysis is characterized thoroughly using different analytical techniques to understand the residual oligomeric units and the type of bond cleavage that occurred. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Materials Zirconium nitrate (Zr(NO3)4), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), nitric acid (HNO3), and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) were purchased from Merck, India. Alkali lignin or kraft lignin (henceforth denoted as lignin), palladium nitrate (Pd(NO3)2), commercial activated carbon (AC) (149 μm; 100 mesh) were procured from Sigma Aldrich. Standard phenolic compounds like acetovanillone, 4-ethyl guaiacol, guaiacol, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxy phenylacetone, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxy-benzene propanol, trans-isoeugenol, 4-methyl guaiacol, 4-propyl guaiacol, and vanillin were procured from Sigma Aldrich. Methanol and tetrahydrofuran were procured from Finar Chemicals, India. The above chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Preparation of Activated Biochar (ABC) The activated biochar (ABC) was prepared from the char derived from microwave pyrolysis of biomass and plastics [18]. A two-stage treatment was adopted to prepare the ABC from the biochar, whose average particle size was ∼300 μm after a ball mill treatment. The preparation of ABC is based on our previous report [16]. The metal oxides and ash impurities were initially removed using a two-stage treatment with HNO3 and KOH. Briefly, 15 g of biochar was mixed with 1 M HNO3 in 300 mL and heated to 80°C with continuous stirring for 12 h. The solution was then filtered, washed till a neutral pH of the filtrate was reached, and finally dried overnight at 110°C. In the second stage, 10 wt.% KOH (300 mL) was added to the solid residue obtained from the first stage, which was then heated to 80°C with constant stirring for 24 h. This aids in the removal of silica present in the biochar. The filtrate was washed until neutral pH was reached and dried overnight at 110°C. Finally, the obtained solids were finely ground, and the sample is named activated biochar (ABC). 2.3 Preparation of Pd and Metal Oxide Loaded AC and ABC The wetness impregnation method was used to load 5 wt.% of metal oxide (MoO3 or ZrO2) on ABC or AC [19]. Typically, the required amount of metal oxide precursor ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O or Zr(NO3)4) and 2 g of support (ABC or AC) were dispersed in 40 mL of deionized (DI) water. The solution was stirred continuously for 6 h at 70°C in an oil bath, and water was gently removed under vacuum at 65°C. The solid obtained was dried at 60°C in a hot air oven, and finally calcined at 300°C for 3 h with a continuous flow of air at 30 mL min−1 in a tubular furnace. The obtained samples were labeled as 5Mo/AC, 5Mo/ABC, 5Zr/AC, and 5Zr/ABC. A similar protocol was used to load 2 wt.% of Pd on 5Mo/AC, 5Mo/ABC, 5Zr/AC, and 5Zr/ABC. The dried and calcined solids were reduced in hydrogen environment (30 mL min−1) in a tubular furnace at 300°C for 3 h. Accordingly, the samples were named 2Pd-5Mo/AC, 2Pd-5Mo/ABC, 2Pd-5Zr/AC, and 2Pd-5Zr/ABC. 2.4 Catalyst Characterization Methods Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the catalysts was performed using a RIGAKU SUPERMINI FLEX 6G X-ray diffractometer at 2 °min−1 scan rate with a Ni-filtered CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 30 mA). The Raman spectra were recorded in the range of 500-4000 cm−1 using BRUKER RFS 27 MultiRAM Fourier Transform (FT)-Raman Spectrometer using Nd-YAG laser source (1064 nm) with LN2-cooled ultra-high sensitivity Ge detector. The elemental CHNS analysis of AC and ABC was performed using Thermo Flash 2000 CHNS analyzer. The oxygen content was determined based on difference. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was performed to evaluate the presence of various functional groups in the lignin. For this, a Cary 630 FTIR spectrometer (Agilent Technologies) was used in attenuated total reflectance (ATR) mode at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The textural properties of all the catalysts were determined in a Quantachrome Autosorb IQ instrument. All the samples were initially degassed at 200°C in vacuum for 3 h. The multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods were used to calculate the specific surface area, and average pore diameter/pore volume of the catalysts, respectively. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were recorded using a FEI Technai T20 instrument operating at 200 kV. The samples were dispersed in IPA with the help of ultrasonication, and a droplet was cast on a carbon-coated copper grid (200 mesh). Finally, they were dried at room temperature for 24 h. 2.5 Catalyst Activity Experiments Catalytic hydrogenolysis experiments were carried out in a 100 mL autoclave (Amar Instruments, India) made of Inconel alloy. The reaction and product separation protocol are described in our earlier works [8,16]. Briefly, the autoclave was loaded with lignin (0.5 g), solvent (40 mL), and catalyst (0.1 g). Before every reaction, the autoclave was flushed multiple times with nitrogen to expel the residual gases in order to maintain an inert atmosphere. The temperature of 240°C and 600 rpm were set in the reactor controller. After holding the reactor temperature for desired amount of time, heating was stopped, and the autoclave was cooled by flowing cold water through the internal coil. The reactor contents were then collected, filtered using Whatman filter paper grade A, and washed multiple times with methanol. The schematic representation of the monomer and product separation protocol is given in Fig. 1 . The solid residue contains the partially depolymerized lignin and the catalyst, while the filtrate contains the converted products. The solid residue retained on the filter paper was dried at 65°C, and the filtrate was recovered using a rotary evaporator operating under vacuum at 50°C. The solids were dissolved in ethyl acetate to precipitate the partially depolymerized lignin and solubilize the hydrogenolysis products. This solution was again filtered, and the mass of the soluble products was calculated. The solution was made up to 25 mL in a standard flask and characterized using a gas chromatograph/mass spectrometer (GC/MS). The residue contains partially depolymerized lignin and the catalyst. The partially depolymerized lignin was separated from the catalyst by washing the solid residue with tetrahydrofuran (THF). The catalyst was then separated by filtration, and the partially depolymerized lignin solubilized in THF was recovered by evaporating the THF using rotary evaporator (G3, hei-VAP core, Heidolph, Germany). The experiments were repeated three times, and the standard deviation in conversion and monomer yields were within ±4%. The following calculations were performed to determine the lignin conversion, the yield of liquid products, and the mass balance achieved. (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = W L − ( W R + W S + W C ) W L × 100 (2) M o n o m e r y i e l d ( w t . % ) = W L Q W L × 100 (3) I n d i v i d u a l m o n o m e r y i e l d ( w t . % ) = M a s s o f m o n o m e r i n l i q u i d W L × 100 (4) M a s s b a l a n c e ( % ) = W R + W S − W C W L × 100 In the above expression, WL, WR, WSL, WC, WLQ, and WS denote initial mass of lignin, residue, ethyl acetate insoluble products, catalyst, ethyl acetate soluble products, and liquid, respectively. 2.6 Product Characterization The monomeric phenols extracted in ethyl acetate solvent from CTH were analyzed using a GC/MS (Shimadzu GC-2010 Plus and QP2020). A DB-5MS capillary column (30 m length × 0.25 mm i.d. × 0.25 μm film thickness) was used. The injector, MS ion source, and interface temperatures were set at 280, 250, and 280°C, respectively. Helium (99.9995%) was used as the carrier gas at a column flow rate of 1.49 mL min−1 and split ratio of 50:1. The column oven was held at 45°C for 1 min, followed by a ramp of 5 °C min−1 up to 250°C, and finally held at 250°C for 10 min. The monomers were recorded in the mass range of 50–500 Da with electron ionization voltage of 70 eV. Pure compound standards of guaiacol, 4-ethyl guaiacol, 4-methyl guaiacol, 4-propyl guaiacol, vanillin, trans-isoeugenol, acetovanillone, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenylacetone, and 4-hydroxy-3-methoxy-benzene propanol were used in different concentrations to generate the calibration plots and the response factors to quantify the products. An average response factor obtained from the standards was considered to quantify other monomeric phenols. The organic functional groups in lignin and regenerated lignin were analyzed using the FTIR spectrometer in ATR mode at a resolution of 4 cm−1 with 64 scans. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of alkali lignin and regenerated lignin was performed in the TG analyzer (SDT Q600, T.A. Instruments) in nitrogen ambience (100 mL min−1) at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. Matrix assisted laser desorption-ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) analysis of regenerated lignin was performed to determine the molecular weight of the residual fragments in lignin after depolymerization. The analysis was performed using an ultrafleXtreme Daltonik GmBh Leipzing instrument (Bruker, Germany). The positive ion MALDI-TOF MS was recorded in linear detection mode using 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid as the matrix. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Characterization of Catalyst The phase of carbon and the crystal structure of the loaded metals were analyzed using XRD. The X-ray diffractograms of the catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2 . A broad hump in the XRD at 2θ ∼22° shows the amorphous nature of carbon, and the sharp peak at 26.6° matches with the crystalline graphitic carbon in AC and ABC [16]. The characteristic peaks of MoO3 and ZrO2 were not observed, which is clear evidence of uniform dispersion of MoO3 and ZrO2 on AC and ABC. However, the characteristic peaks of Pd0 appeared in all the catalysts that matched with JCPDS 46-1043. In 2Pd-5Mo/AC, the peaks at 39.9, 46.4, 68, and 81.8° correspond to (111), (200), (220), and (311), respectively. These peaks of Pd0 were also observed for 2Pd-5Zr/AC. The additional peaks at 81 and 86° in 2Pd-5Zr/ABC correspond to (311) and (222), respectively. More number of characteristic peaks of Pd0 are evident when 2Pd-5Zr is supported over ABC than over AC. The intensities and full-width half maximum (FWHM) of Pd0 at (111) plane are distinct with the change of AC or ABC support. This is partially attributed to the aggregation of Pd nanoparticles [20], and can also be due to the variation in textural properties of the support. Similar results are reported in the literature for Pd supported on different carbons (activated carbon, graphite, and graphitic carbon nanofiber) [21]. Pd supported on graphene nanotubes exhibited an average pore diameter of 4.8 nm and a surface area of 74 m2 g−1. In contrast, Pd that was supported on conventional activated carbon exhibited a high surface area of 875 m2 g−1 and an average pore size of 3.2 nm. Due to the high surface area and low average pore diameter, the aggregation of Pd0 particles is low in AC supported catalyst than the ABC-based one. The FT-Raman spectroscopy is used to characterize the carbonaceous materials, and especially to identify the degree of structural disorder [22]. The Raman spectra of AC and ABC are shown in Fig. 3 . Two sharp, high-intensity peaks are observed at 1280 cm−1 (D-band) and 1595 cm−1 (G-band). The D-band is attributed to defects or disorders of the vibrations of sp3-bonded amorphous carbon. Grain boundaries, oxygen vacancies, and the amorphous nature of carbon result in the D-band. The G-band corresponds to sp2-bonded carbon atoms in a hexagonal graphitic ring or in the form of chains [23,24]. The degree of structural disorder and graphitization of the carbon material is estimated by the (ID/IG)-value. The (ID/IG)-value of AC (0.81) is lower than that of ABC (1.25), which indicates that a high degree of graphitization exists in AC [22,25]. This is substantiated by the high-intensity of the characteristic carbon peak as observed in the XRD profile of AC (Fig. 2). Two smaller additional bands, D2 and I, appeared in the form of shoulder peaks around 1470 and 1185 cm−1 in AC, respectively. These were further confirmed by the deconvolution of the D, G, D2 and I bands, which prove that these two small bands are indeed not noise. Importantly, from the deconvoluted curves, there seems to be a blue shift of the peaks, especially in the case of ABC, which is attributed to the presence of more concentrated clusters of smaller aromatic structures at the surface. Such features have been observed during the oxidation of activated carbon, wherein the oxides are attached through the olefinic bonds that get sandwiched between the aromatic clusters and the surface oxygen groups [26]. This is likely to occur in ABC, as it was prepared via nitric acid oxidation of the pyrolysis biochar. The D2 band is due to the co-existence of sp3 and sp2 phases, while the I band refers to the distribution of amorphous carbon in the interstices of the graphitic structures, and sometimes to the non-homogeneous nature of the surface due to the presence of ash impurities/ions. These two bands pertain to the stretching vibrations involved in the amorphous carbon phase. The D2 and I bands are distinct in ABC than in AC, which points to the significance of the amorphous carbon fraction in ABC than in AC. Based on elemental analyses, the C, H, N and O content in AC was 69.4, 2.8, 0.9, and 23.9 wt.%, respectively, while in ABC, it was 75.3, 1.9, 1.2 and 17.2 wt.%, respectively, on a dry basis. Sulfur was not detected. FTIR spectra of AC and ABC are shown in Fig. S1 (Supplementary Information). The vibrational bands observed in the FTIR include C=O stretching (1735 cm−1), C–H bending (1375 cm−1). Except these two peaks no other significant peak was observed for both AC and ABC. This shows that the support materials are reasonably carbonaceous. The ABC, prepared using microwave pyrolysis, contains more carbon due to the greater extent of carbonization reactions that are prevalent during pyrolysis. The textural properties of all the catalysts are shown in Table 1 . Compared to ABC-based catalysts, commercial AC-supported catalysts possessed a high surface area, which is in line with a previous report [16]. The micropore area is higher than the external surface area in 2Pd-5Zr/ABC. The pore volume of 2Pd-5Zr/ABC is slightly more than that of 2Pd-5Mo/ABC. High pore volume resulted in a high micropore area, and the microporous structure is predominant in AC. Mesopores are found in ABC, which is evident from BJH pore size analysis. In 2Pd-5Mo/AC, the crystallite size of Pd0 (111) is 2.1 Å, which is higher than 2Pd-5Mo/ABC. Similarly, crystallite size of 2.5 Å is calculated for 2Pd-5Zr/AC, which is higher than the corresponding ABC catalyst. Finally, the crystallite size of Pd0 is more when it is supported on AC than ABC. The BET isotherms and pore size distribution of all the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 , respectively. The metals supported on AC exhibited the H3 hysteresis loop with Type IV isotherm. Essentially, the presence of a non-rigid aggregate of plate-like particles is demonstrated for this type of hysteresis loop [27]. However, the average BJH pore size is in the range of 1.5-1.6 nm. Pd-metal oxide (MoO3 or ZrO2)-supported on ABC catalysts showed Type III isotherm, which demonstrates a relatively weak interaction between the adsorbent and the adsorbate. Interestingly, open hysteresis loop was observed for ABC-supported catalyst. From Fig. 4 it is clear that the adsorption curve is not consistent with the desorption curve, which gives rise to hysteresis loop. The H3-type hysteresis loop indicates plate-like particles with slit pore morphology. This is typically observed in clay minerals due to the presence of lamellar structures with slit pores. Similar open hysteresis loops for carbon materials are also reported in the literature. Aqdam et al. [28] reported similar open loop hysteresis of bio-nanocomposite-based nanofibrils made of whey protein and montmorillonite nano-clay. The presence of non-rigid plate like particles with slit pores lead to open loops. The biochar obtained from co-pyrolysis of polyethylene and different parts of corn stalks (skins, pith, leaves) activated with potassium hydroxide [25], and rice husk biochar activated with nitric acid [27] showed similar results. Sun et al. [29] observed H4-type hysteresis for the biochar synthesized via pyrolysis of crab shell, which was further modified using mineral acids. The open loop was attributed to the presence of mesopores. Besides, similar observations are reported for activated carbon obtained from Vitisvinifera leaf litter by carbonization [30], and discarded biodiesel waste–derived Jatropha shell using zinc chloride activation method [31]. From the pore size distribution plots, it is evident that the pore size is in a narrow range in the case of AC-supported catalysts, while, in addition to the 2 nm pores, larger pores or cavities are present in the case of ABC-based catalysts. The HRTEM images of Pd-metal oxide (MoO3 or ZrO2) supported on AC and ABC are shown in Fig. 6 . In all the catalysts, evenly dispersed particles are observed. The absence of peaks in XRD for the metal oxides substantiate this. Pd0 is characterized by a face-centered cubic (FCC) crystalline plane at (111) with a d-spacing of 0.225 nm in all the catalysts, and similar results are observed in a previous report [16]. However, in 2Pd-5Zr/AC, Pd0 (022) is noticed in the FCC lattice with a d-spacing of 0.14 nm. ZrO2 is found in both catalysts (supported on AC or ABC) in the tetragonal crystal system with a d-spacing 0.17 nm corresponding to (021), which matches with JCPDS 54-1089. MoO3 was observed in 2Pd-5Mo/ABC with a d-spacing of 0.26 (111) and 0.173 (112). The orthorhombic crystal system of MoO3 matches well with the JCPDS 85-2405. Metallic oxide diffraction planes were assigned based on the d-spacing values obtained from the lattice fringes. In order to quantify the actual loading of the metals on the support, energy-dispersive X-ray analysis was performed, which showed that the amount of Pd in all the catalysts is 1.68±0.2%, while Zr and Mo varied in the range of 5-6%. The catalyst acidity, which may be due to the support or the Lewis acidic metal oxides, is also an important property that influences its activity. In an earlier study, the nature of acid sites and their respective amounts were quantified for ABC-based catalysts using NH3-temperature programmed desorption and the pyridine diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy techniques [16]. The DRIFT results showed the strong adsorption band at 1430–1440 cm−1 corresponding to the Lewis acidity imparted by the metal oxides. The total acidity followed the trend: 2Pd-5Zr/ABC (0.85 mmol g−1) < 2Pd-5Mo/ABC (2.7 mmol g−1) < ABC (1.05 mmol g−1). Besides, AC was found to possess low acidity (< 0.4 mmol g−1) than ABC owing to the use of acids in the preparation of ABC in the activation step [16]. Therefore, it is anticipated that the total acidity and the nature of Lewis or Brønsted acid sites in the AC-supported catalysts will also follow a similar trend as observed for ABC supported catalysts. While it is known that the incorporation of Pd partially blocks the acidic sites offered by the metal oxides, the relatively high acidity of Mo-based catalyst is due to an increase in Brønsted acid sites. 3.2 Catalytic Activity Experiments The conversion of lignin, total monomer yield, and the yields of specific monomers obtained from catalytic activity experiments are shown in Table 2 . Without a catalyst, lignin conversion and monomer yield were 29.2% and 18.6 wt.%, respectively, with alkyl guaiacols as the major products at 4.2 wt.% yield. Lower yields of guaiacol and alkene guaiacols were observed, which may be due to the random cleavage of C–C and C–O bonds in lignin. When lignin is subjected to transfer hydrogenolysis using 2Pd-5Mo/ABC, the conversion and monomer yield were 41.0% and 29.2 wt.%, respectively. Maximum yield of alkyl guaiacols (7.1 wt.%) was obtained. With 2Pd-5Mo/AC, the conversion and monomer yields increased by 11.7% and 20%, respectively, compared to 2Pd-5Mo/ABC. The yields of alkyl guaiacols and vanillin/vanillin derivatives were 10.3 and 12 wt.%, respectively. The difference in C–C bond dissociation energy and random cleavage of the alkyl side chain results in the production of alkyl guaiacols [32]. Further, the hydrogenation and dehydroxylation of alkene and alcohol guaiacols might also be a reason for the high yield of alkyl guaiacols. The homolytic cleavage of the C–O bond in β-O-4 linkages of lignin, followed by the C–C bond cleavage result in the production of vanillin/vanillin derivatives at high yields [33]. Mostly, multiple bonds in lignin like α-O-4, β-O-4, α-1, and β-1 undergo hydrogen-assisted bond cleavage reactions concurrently to produce increased selectivity to vanillin derivatives [34]. The other monomers include phenol, 2-methyl-phenol, 4-ethyl phenol, catechol, 4-methyl-1,2-benzenediol, 2,6-dimethoxyphenol, guaiacylacetone, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxy-benzenepropanol, and 4-propyl-1,3-benzenediol. Only minor improvement in conversion was observed with 2Pd-5Zr/AC as compared to 2Pd-5Zr/ABC. The yields of guaiacol and alkyl guaiacols are significant in the case of 2Pd-5Zr/ABC than in 2Pd-5Zr/AC. However, alkene guaiacols and vanillin/vanillin derivatives are produced in significant amounts using 2Pd-5Zr/AC. The production of other non-selective monomers was reduced by 45% when the support changed from ABC to AC with 2Pd-5Zr. In summary, guaiacol and alkyl guaiacols are observed mostly with 2Pd-5Zr/ABC, while vanillin/vanillin derivatives and alkene guaiacols are obtained using 2Pd-5Zr/AC. Alkyl guaiacols, vanillin/vanillin derivatives are the primary monomeric phenols when 2Pd-5Mo/AC is used. The AC-based catalyst showed better catalytic activity due to high graphitization and lesser amorphous carbon, which is demonstrated by FT-Raman analysis. Similar results were reported in the literature for Fe-Fe3C/C based catalyst, where 86% selectivity to guaiacol and substituted guaiacols in supercritical ethanol at 290°C and 5 h was obtained [32]. The Lewis acidic metal oxides promote dehydroxylation of Cγ and aids in the cleavage of ether bonds in the lignin. It is evident from Table 2 that the 2Pd-5Mo/AC catalyst exhibits better activity than other catalysts in terms of lignin conversion and the quality of the phenolic products, which can be attributed to the acidity offered by Mo, high surface area and microporous nature of the AC support. 3.3 Effect of Solvent The solvent plays a vital role in selectively converting lignin to monomers, specifically in CTH. The product yields and lignin conversion from CTH of alkali lignin using short-chain alcohols are reported in Table 3 . With 2Pd-5Mo/AC, the lignin conversion followed the trend EtOH (50.4%) > IPA (45.8%) > MeOH (40.6%). The use of MeOH demonstrated a lower monomer yield than EtOH and IPA. However, the monomer yield was observed to be similar with EtOH and IPA. The yields of guaiacol, alkyl guaiacols, and alkene guaiacols were 4.2, 10.3, and 3.4 wt.%, respectively, when IPA was used as the solvent. However, the product yields were low with MeOH. MeOH and EtOH are mostly dehydrogenated at supercritical conditions or at elevated temperatures. Under mild operating conditions, IPA is dehydrogenated to the stable compound, acetone [5,35]. The secondary alcohol group in IPA imparts better electron release rate due to the induction effect than that in MeOH and EtOH [4]. One possible reason for the low yield of monomeric phenols with MeOH is due to the poor rate of stabilization of the intermediate monomers, which is important to stop their repolymerization to oligomers. The product distribution from lignin hydrogenolysis differs significantly depending on the solvent used due to its structure and reactivity [5]. The yield of other monomeric products was low (6.1 wt.%) in the case of IPA, whereas it was high (∼12.5 wt.%) with MeOH and EtOH. Table 4 [8,9,11,16,36,37] presents a comparison of salient results from this study with the literature on hydrogenolysis of lignin using different catalysts and H-donating solvents / molecular hydrogen. It is evident that the use of molecular hydrogen improves the lignin conversion, liquid yield and the yield/selectivity to C9 phenols. Nevertheless, the results from this study are encouraging as the conversion and product yields are comparable with that using molecular hydrogen with a potential for improvement. Importantly, the catalyst used in this study demonstrates better activity than many other catalysts reported in the literature. Schemes 1 and 2 depict the proposed pathways for the formation of various phenolics observed in this study during CTH. The active metal sites adsorb the hydrogen transferred by the solvent, and promote the cleavage of either β-O-4 or α-O-4 linkages of lignin. The hydrogen-assisted C–C and C–O bond cleavage and hydrogenation reactions result in the production of the phenolic compounds like alkyl guaiacols (ethyl guaiacol, propyl guaiacol), alcohol guaiacol (propanol guaiacol, homovanillyl alcohol), alkene guaiacol (isoeugenol), and vanillin and its derivatives. The entire reaction mechanism is assembled based on literature reports [38,39]. Vanillin and its derivatives are produced by the cleavage of β-O-4 and 5-5 type bonds, while the cleavage of α-O-4 bonds in the lignin gives rise to guaiacol derivatives [40]. Further, the elimination of methoxy group in the guaiacol results in the formation of alkyl phenols. Wang et al. [41] subjected different lignin and lignin model compounds to oxidative depolymerization, and showed that phenolic aldehydes like vanillin can be produced from lignins that contain more β-O-4 linkages. In the present work, the formation of vanillin and its derivatives in significant amounts can be attributed, atleast partially, to the presence of ZrO2 that possess oxygen reversible properties to promote oxidation reaction. These observations are in line with Totong et al. [36] who reported the catalytic depolymerization of alkali lignin over Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. The lignin yielded >2 wt.% of vanillin derivatives in presence of water-MeOH co-solvent, which was ascribed to the CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst with oxygen reversible properties. Saini et al. [33] observed the formation of vanillin, homovanillic acid, acetovanillone and guaiacol at 64%, 8.3%, 7.8% and 6.6% selectivities, respectively, during low-temperature depolymerization of alkali lignin in water-ethanol solvent system. In a recent work, vanillin (6.4 wt.%) and homovanillic acid (2.1 wt.%) were obtained from pine wood biomass via reductive catalytic fractionation, and the formation of vanillin is proposed via cleavage of β-O-4 bonds in the methanol-extracted lignin [42]. 3.4 Characterization of Partially Depolymerized Lignin The TG mass loss and differential TG (DTG) profiles of regenerated lignins are presented in Fig. 7 . The raw lignin decomposed in a wide range of 150-600°C. From the DTG plots, multiple regions of decomposition are evident. These correspond to DTG peaks centered at ∼142 °C, ∼230 °C, ∼280 °C and ∼440 °C. The peaks signify the volatilization of different oligomeric fragments in regenerated lignin. The first peak is dominant only with 2Pd-5Mo/AC catalyst, which can be correlated, atleast partially, with the high yield of low boiling chemicals like propyl guaiacol. The peaks at 230°C and 280°C that are apparently merged with each other can be related to the derivatives of vanillin and vanillin derivatives, and the dimeric/trimeric phenols. The magnitude of the last decomposition peak is similar for all regenerated lignins, which corresponds to the devolatilization of the oligomers with more than four or five phenolic units. The intensity of the central decomposition region is higher in 2Pd-5Mo/ABC than in 2Pd-5Mo/AC, which can be attributed, at least partially, to the release of heavy monomers, dimers and trimers. A similar trend was observed in the case of 2Pd-5Zr/ABC vs 2Pd-5Zr/AC. Metals (Pd, Mo, Zr) supported over ABC produce more heavy oligomers compared to AC. This may be due to the lower surface area and lesser degree of graphitization in ABC support. The TG analysis of regenerated lignins obtained after subjecting to different solvents using 2Pd-5Mo/AC is shown in Fig. 7 (c). The intensity of the central decomposition region qualitatively followed the trend: EtOH > MeOH > IPA. The low intensity of the heavy oligomeric peaks and the high intensity of heavy monomeric peaks in the case of IPA solvent proves that facile depolymerization of lignin and its oligomers occurred, especially because of the easy donation of hydrogen as compared to MeOH and EtOH that facilitated the hydrogenolysis reactions. The FTIR spectra of regenerated lignins obtained after hydrogenolysis using different catalysts and solvents are depicted in Fig. 8 . The peaks corresponding to O–H stretch due to aliphatic (1-3330 cm−1), C–H stretch in aromatic methoxy (2-2970 cm−1), carboxylic O–H stretch (3-2930 cm−1), methylene and methyl groups (4-2870 cm−1), aromatic skeleton vibration (5-1590 cm−1, 6-1510 cm−1), C–H deformation combined with the aromatic skeleton (7-1460 cm−1), guaiacyl (G) ring + C=O stretch (9-1250 cm−1), syringyl (S) ring stretch (10-1120 cm−1), and aromatic ring and primary alcohol (11-1010 cm−1) were observed in all the samples. All these functional group assignments are in good agreement with the literature [43]. The FTIR spectra of raw and regenerated lignin were similar, demonstrating that the functional groups are identical. However, the relative intensities of the peaks changed significantly. The negligible intensity of (1) in regenerated lignin as compared to raw lignin shows that aliphatic –OH is removed when catalysts are used. Intensities of (5), (6), (7), (9), (10), and (11) also decreased, which confirms the deportation of the aromatic ring because of C–O bond cleavage. Interestingly, the peak centered at (8-1325 cm−1) appeared in regenerated lignin, while it was absent in raw lignin. This is attributed to the condensed form of G-ring and S-ring, i.e., G-ring substituted in position 5 of S-ring [44]. The bimolecular condensation reactions of the unstable monomers lead to the appearance of this peak [43]. Interestingly, the intensities of (2), (3), and (4) increased to a minimal extent after depolymerization. This is due to the possible esterification reactions [45], or due to the presence of the propyl phenolic groups in regenerated lignin [46]. Fig. 8(c) shows the FTIR spectra of regenerated lignins obtained by using different solvents in CTH. Qualitatively, similar peaks were observed. The intensity of the peaks (2), (3), and (4) for the regenerated lignin obtained from CTH using different solvents followed the trend: IPA > EtOH > MeOH. The MALDI-TOF spectra of regenerated lignins obtained after hydrogenolysis were analyzed for all catalytic experiments (Fig. 9 ). The molecular weight range has been classified into monomers (m/z: <250), dimers (m/z: 275-450), trimers (m/z: 450-600), and tetramers (m/z: >600) [47,48]. The intensity and density of peaks of trimers and tetramers in the mass spectra obtained from experiments conducted with different catalysts and different solvents are almost similar. This is corroborated by the second decomposition region in TGA (Fig. 7), which is partially due to the condensation of monomer radicals via coupling reactions that lead to the formation of trimers and tetramers. The mass spectra of regenerated lignin obtained using 2Pd-5Mo/AC and 2Pd-5Mo/ABC are depicted in Fig. 9 (a,b). The intensity and density of peaks corresponding to dimers are low in 2Pd-5Mo/AC than in 2Pd-5Mo/ABC, which points to relatively more dimerization when ABC-based catalyst is used. Significant weight loss was observed in the TG analysis of 2Pd-5Mo/ABC. Fig. 9 (c,d) shows a similar trend in peak and their intensities in 2Pd-5Zr/AC and 2Pd-5Zr/ABC. When EtOH was used as solvent, several dimer peaks were observed with strong intensity. The intensity of the peaks was low when IPA was used. These observations are also substantiated by TG analysis in Fig. 7, where significant mass loss occurred in the case of EtOH than MeOH and IPA. IPA can easily donate hydrogen under mild reaction conditions, owing to the inductive effect than MeOH and EtOH [5]. It is evident from the mass spectra that the major peaks differ in their mass by 17-18 Da, which points to the dehydration reaction during lignin depolymerization. This is evident from m/z (Da): 207-225, 247-265, 344-362, 470-488, 694-712. Decarbonylation reactions are evident from the difference of 28 Da in the mass, viz., 181-209. The mass of 181-182 Da can be attributed to the hydrogenated forms of coniferyl alcohol or guaiacyl acetone or hydrogenated version of hydroxy eugenol, while the other major monomer peak at 207-209 Da can be attributed to dimethoxy cinnamic acid and its hydrogenated forms. The exact identification of the molecular structure of these oligomeric phenols would require an MS/MS analysis of the parent/daughter ions in a mass spectrometer, which is a possible scope for future work. 4 Conclusions In this study, two types of carbon supports (AC and ABC) with Pd-Lewis acid metal oxides (Mo and Zr) were evaluated for the transfer hydrogenolysis of lignin to monomeric phenols, especially alkyl guaiacols and vanillin/vanillin derivatives. The crystallite size of Pd (111) was in the range of 2-2.5 Å with AC support, whereas it was ∼1.5 Å in the case of ABC. The ID/IG values of AC and ABC were 0.81 and 1.25, respectively, which confirmed better degree of graphitization in AC. The use of AC-based catalysts resulted in better lignin conversion (∼ 45.8%) as compared to ABC-based ones (39-41%) when isopropyl alcohol was used as the solvent. The use of 2Pd-5Mo/AC resulted in better yields of alkyl guaiacols (10.3 wt.%), and vanillin/vanillin derivatives (12 wt.%) at 240°C and 3 h with isopropyl alcohol. The liquid yield followed the trend MeOH (26.9 wt.%) < EtOH (35.8 wt.%) ≈ IPA (36.1 wt.%). The condensed form of guaiacyl- and syringyl-units were observed through FTIR spectroscopy of the regenerated lignin. The MALDI-TOF analysis showed that using IPA resulted in lesser dimer formation than that using MeOH and EtOH. coredata.dc:description: Lignin valorization is the key to sustainability of second-generation bioethanol refineries. In this study, the catalytic activities of Pd-Lewis acid metal oxides (Mo, Zr) supported on commercial activated carbon (AC) and activated biochar (ABC) were evaluated for the selective production of monomeric phenols from alkali lignin through transfer hydrogenolysis. The catalysts were thoroughly characterized for phase, degree of graphitization, textural properties, and metal dispersion. The Pd crystallite size was 2.1-2.5 Å in the case of AC-supported catalysts, while it was smaller (1.4-1.5 Å) for ABC-supported catalysts. AC exhibited better degree of graphitization than ABC. 2%Pd-5%Mo supported on AC showed good catalytic activity for the production of guaiacol, alkyl guaiacols, alkene guaiacols, and vanillin derivatives, and their respective yields were 4.2, 10.3, 3.4, and 12 wt.%. Compared to other alcohols like methanol and ethanol, the use of isopropyl alcohol as solvent resulted in better yields of guaiacol, alkyl guaiacols and alkene guaiacols. Condensation reactions of the guaiacyl unit and syringyl unit were confirmed through Fourier transform infrared spectroscopic analysis of the residue. Dimerization of monomeric phenols was observed with Pd-metal oxide supported on ABC than with AC-based catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Lignin Depolymerization to Guaiacol and Vanillin Derivatives via Catalytic Transfer Hydrogenolysis using Pd-Lewis Metal Oxide Supported on Activated Carbon Catalysts
